Chapter on Sages, Chapter 5. The afflictions have already been explained. The practice will now be explained.
The first is called beginner, the next is already practiced,
Those who have already transcended contemplation should be known as the third type.
There are three kinds of practice: beginner, already practiced, and already transcended contemplation.
The beginner is the turning of impurity, contemplating the realm of the mind that has not yet been attained.
The already practiced is the turning of the mindfulness of the characteristics of suffering, the wholesome roots of the undetermined stage that have not yet been attained.
Above this, it should be known that contemplation has already been transcended, because above this is the path of the single vehicle.

Moreover, the contemplation of impurity is also of three kinds of practice. That is to say, starting from the toes and going up to the top of the head, removing the skin, blood, and flesh, and contemplating with the mind, this is called the beginner.

In this skeleton, do not generate thoughts of pervading the great earth. Also, contemplate the skeleton without generating thoughts. Those skeletons turn and face each other, blown and gathered by a great wind, dissolving into a mass of snow. This is called already practiced.
Contemplating the skeleton briefly returns to one's own body. In the object of perception, purely and peacefully contemplating only one color, this is called having already transcended contemplation.
Thus, up to the brief realm, one should know that the wholesome roots gradually increase.
One should know that all the remaining skillful means and wholesome roots are also like this.
The practice has already been explained. The rest will now be explained.
If frightened by this affliction, one should stay far away from the sages,
And listen well to the skillful means that are truly and fully equipped.
If means if there are seeds, if there are skillful means, if there is discrimination.
This means explaining the afflictions in sequence.
Afflictions means being tormented.
It is also free from all impurities, but the faults of afflictions are like poisoned food, therefore it is said to be free from afflictions.
The root of all fears is giving rise to various karmas and various births.
Far away means to extinguish them repeatedly.
Noble ones refers to those in the stage of correct determination, namely the seven types of noble ones and ordinary beings of true reality.
Correctly and fully endowed with reality means abiding in the true path.
Skillfully listen means to listen single-mindedly to the path of skillful means.
Skillful means refers to the skillful means of all wholesome dharmas that lead to liberation, such as giving, and so forth, but not only the path.
Oppressed by the three kinds of suffering, the world is unable to awaken - in order to cultivate concentration.
First, within one's own body and mind, bind the mind and make it stable,
Desiring to bind the consciousness and feet, in order to eliminate the enemy of wisdom.
First means prior.
One's own body and mind refers to a single part of one's own body, such as between the eyebrows, the tip of the nose, or the toes.
Binding means establishing the mind on an object and preventing it from scattering.
What is established?
It means that by the power of the mind's concentration, wisdom arises.
Question:
Why is it so?
Answer:
Because the mind flows and does not abide, it is bound to a single object. Only by a single mind can one know the truth without confusion.
Question:
Why is it bound to a single object?
Answer:
In order to destroy the enemies of wisdom.
The enemies of wisdom are the afflictions that should be eliminated.
Although one observes the bodies of others as if observing corpses,
The sutras say:
Because they are distant causes.
This refers to observing proximate causes.
Moreover, because it accords with all the gateways to liberation. That is to say, observing white bones and body parts accords with the three gateways to liberation.
Observing corpses only accords with the single gateway to liberation of impurity.
The three gateways to liberation are the observation of impurity, mindfulness of breathing, and the observation of the skillful means of the elements.

Those with lust are liberated by the contemplation of impurity, those with discursive thoughts are liberated by the contemplation of breathing, and those with views are liberated by the contemplation of the elements, practicing according to the teacher's instructions and their own inclinations.
The contemplation of impurity and the contemplation of breathing are explained in detail in the sutra section.
The contemplation of the elements will be explained now.

This is because the wisdom eye of ordinary people is obscured by incorrect thought, they do not contemplate the true Dharma of dependent origination, the seeds of past karma and afflictions are innumerable dharmas, and the five aggregates arise with the notion of accumulation.
Out of delusion, they cling to the view of self and other in the dependently arisen activities, bound by various wrong views.

Sometimes, practicing and befriending the wise, they hear the true Dharma and give rise to correct thought, and then they are able to skillfully contemplate the various natures, various activities, and various characteristics of this body in their own body's elements, referring to the six elements such as earth and so forth.

Because the earth element is moistened by the water element, they do not separate. Because the water element is held by the earth element, it does not flow and scatter. Because the fire element matures, it does not rot and decay. Because the wind element moves and shakes, it can grow. Because the space element is empty, food and so forth can enter and exit. Because the consciousness element combines, there is something produced.
Moreover, contemplate this body from the feet to the top of the head, filled with various impurities and filth.

Contemplate this form as if a strong wind were scattering accumulated sand. In the formless dharmas, observe the continuity of past and future as different parts. One who contemplates in this way obtains the seed of the gate of liberation of emptiness;
Disgusted with and not enjoying that birth and death, one obtains the seed of the gate of liberation of wishlessness;
Not enjoying birth and death, one correctly heads towards nirvana, and obtains the seed of the gate of liberation of signlessness.
If one obtains the thought of non-action in this way, and contemplates that all conditioned things are completely scattered and destroyed, this is called the completion of the method of the elements.
Question:
Having contemplated in this way, what should one do next?
Answer:
This skillful means is the definitive true characteristics of the body,
All feelings and one's own mind, the Dharma is also observed in this way.

After the practitioner has abided in each of the practices of impurity meditation, mindfulness of breathing, and the observation of the elements, they observe the truth of the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas.
Truth means non-erroneous.
Characteristics are of two kinds:
Namely, specific characteristics and common characteristics.
The characteristics of form are the specific characteristics of the body, the four [great elements] and the derivatives;
The characteristics of following awareness are the specific characteristics of feelings;
The characteristics of consciousness are the specific characteristics of the mind.

The mindfulness of dharmas has various dharmas, with various different characteristics. Following knowledge is the characteristics of conceptualization, and the characteristics of intention are like this.
The common characteristics will be explained later.
Question:
This mindfulness should be explained as one, established like the great earth. Distinguishing between contaminated and uncontaminated should be explained as
Second, distinguishing soft, medium, and superior should be explained as three. Distinguishing this with and without outflows should
be explained as six. Distinguishing with and without outflows in the body, etc. should be explained as eight. Distinguishing the nine grades should

be explained as nine. Distinguishing internally, externally, and both internally and externally in the body, etc. should be explained as twelve. Distinguishing the nine grades with and without outflows should

be explained as eighteen. Distinguishing with and without outflows in the soft, medium, and superior of the body, etc. should be explained as twenty-four. Distinguishing the body, etc. as internal, external, both internal and external, as aversion, as non-enjoyment, and as observation should be explained as thirty-six. Distinguishing the nine grades with and without outflows in the body, etc. should be explained as seventy-two. If distinguished moment by moment, it should be explained as immeasurable.
Why are the four establishments of mindfulness taught?
Answer:

Because the four inversions, the four establishments of mindfulness, the four abodes of consciousness, and the aggregates are the objects of cultivation by the four kinds of cultivation, the four kinds of cultivated dharmas are taught.

Because it treats the inversion of thinking of impurity as purity, it is said to be mindfulness of the body. Because it treats the inversion of thinking of suffering as happiness, it is said to be mindfulness of feelings. Because it treats the inversion of thinking of the impermanent as permanent, it is said to be mindfulness of mind. Because it treats the inversion of thinking of non-self as self, it is said to be mindfulness of dharmas.
In this way, the other types should be explained as appropriate.
Question:
How is this mindfulness fulfilled?
Answer:
It is fulfilled by two causes and conditions, namely, the destruction of objects and the increase of wholesome roots.
As for the destruction of objects, it means the destruction of objects by the most subtle and momentary, according to their meaning.
As for the increase of wholesome roots, it means relying on the middle and increasing the middle based on the soft wholesome roots.
This is called fulfillment.
Question:
Why is mindfulness of the body explained first, and up to mindfulness of dharmas?
Answer:
Because it arises in accordance with.
The World-Honored One speaks of three kinds of accordance:
arising in accordance with, speaking in accordance with, and uninterrupted equality in accordance with.
As for arising in accordance with, it refers to the foundations of mindfulness and dhyÄna.
For the formless realm practitioner, the body mindfulness up to the later arising of dharma mindfulness, therefore the World-Honored One first spoke of body mindfulness up to dharma mindfulness.
One should know that dhyÄna and formless [concentrations] are also like this.

As for speaking of what is in accordance with [the path], the right efforts, bases of supernatural power, faculties, powers, enlightenment factors, and path factors are in one moment, with vigor possessing the four right efforts, speaking of what is easy.
Already arisen unwholesome dharmas, with skillful means causing them to be cut off, up to already arisen wholesome dharmas, with skillful means causing them to abide, speaking of them in this way.
In this way, the right efforts, because of what is done, speak of the four right efforts, not because of their own nature.

As for what is in accordance with the uninterrupted [path] and so forth, speaking of the truths, the practitioner first enters the uninterrupted [path] of suffering and so forth, therefore speaking of them first, speaking of them in this way in detail.
Question:
Why does the practitioner first give rise to body mindfulness up to dharma mindfulness?
Answer:
Because they are coarse.
Which of the five aggregates are coarse?
It is said that the four great elements and the derived matter are thus observed first.
Although feeling is not form, it is said next because it is coarse in practice, that is, feeling of the hands and feet and so on.

Although conceptualization and the aggregate of volitional activities are coarse, they are not consciousness, but they are combined with nirvana and established as the mindfulness of dharmas, therefore they are the most subtle, and thus the mind is observed first and dharmas are observed later.
Although all are dharmas, this is established because the conceptualization of dharmas is fulfilled, therefore it is said to be the mindfulness of dharmas and not the others.
Just as the dharma entry is explained in the chapter on realms, it is the same here. Fulfilled conceptualization means that in sound it is conceptualization, and in meaning it is fulfilled.
Question:
How many kinds of mindfulness are there?
Answer:
Mindfulness is said to be of three kinds: intrinsic nature, together with its companions,
And also said to be objects, such as the wisdom of hearing and so on.

The three kinds of mindfulness are said to have their own nature and also to have objects. The three kinds of mindfulness are mindfulness of one's own nature, shared mindfulness, and mindfulness of objects.
Mindfulness of one's own nature refers to non-inverted wisdom.
Why is it so?
As it is said, observing the body in accordance with the body is the task of mindfulness, because it does not forget to give rise to conditions.
In order to eliminate the fault of one's own nature, mindfulness is taught.
Shared mindfulness is the dharma of the same fruit as right wisdom.
As the World-Honored One said:
Bhiká¹£us!
The accumulation of good dharmas refers to the four mindfulnesses. This is the correct teaching.
Mindfulness of objects refers to all dharmas.
As it is said:
Bhiká¹£us!
All dharmas are said to be the four mindfulnesses. This is the correct teaching.
Because it includes the complete and briefly takes objects.
Shared mindfulness eliminates afflictions, not the others.
Although the intrinsic nature of mindfulness has a brief object, it is not sufficient to include the complete path to eliminate afflictions.
The mindfulness of conditions, although it includes various means, still has a scattered object, so the brief object path eliminates afflictions.
Question:
Are only these three kinds of mindfulness, or are the others also like this?
Answer:
The wisdom of hearing and so forth is also like this.
The others are also of three kinds, namely, hearing, thinking, and cultivation.
Hearing means always arising from the place of names, receiving sutras, precepts, and abhidharma from a teacher.
Thinking means either arising from the place of thinking or being apart from thinking.
Cultivation means arising completely apart from names.
It is like three people learning to swim, one just starting, one halfway there, and one very skilled.
The one just starting stays close to the shore, the one halfway there may be close or far, and the very skilled one is far from the shore.
The first person is like the wisdom of hearing, the second is like the wisdom of thinking, and the third is like the wisdom of cultivation.
Cultivated wisdom can eliminate afflictions and is called permanent separation because it is right concentration.
The two kinds of meaninglessness are unreasonable.
Why?
Because it leads to cultivated wisdom.
Cultivated wisdom is endowed with the four establishments of mindfulness:
body, feelings, mind, and dharmas.
Among them, the establishment of mindfulness of dharmas eliminates afflictions, not the others, because it has a comprehensive object, not because of the others.
Because it arises with a specific object, the establishment of mindfulness of dharmas is also not meaningless.
The establishment of mindfulness of dharmas is of two kinds:
perishable objects and imperishable objects.

If wisdom takes form as its object, it is the establishment of mindfulness of body. If it takes feelings as its object, it is the establishment of mindfulness of feelings. If it takes mind as its object, it is the establishment of mindfulness of mind. If it takes conceptualization, volition, and the unconditioned as its object, it is the establishment of mindfulness of dharmas with imperishable objects.
The other establishments of mindfulness will now be explained.
Entering the dharmas and comprehensively observing, one attains the true characteristics of dharmas,
That these four are impermanent, empty, without self, and not blissful.

As for entering the Dharma and comprehensively contemplating to attain the true characteristics of dharmas, the practitioner enters the mindfulness of dharmas with undifferentiated objects. Cultivating each mindfulness, they comprehensively contemplate the specific and general characteristics of all dharmas, and then enter the mindfulness of dharmas with differentiated objects.
Form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness as objects. In this way, four, three, five aggregates as objects.
This mindfulness of dharmas accomplishes mindfulness of the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas, and with a single realization comprehensively contemplates and transcends.
How is this so?
These four are impermanent, empty, without self, and not blissful.

Using the aspects of impermanence, etc., comprehensively contemplate all contaminated dharmas. Because they cease moment by moment, they are impermanent. Because they are apart from permanence, etc., they are empty. Because they are not self-controlled, they are without self. Because they truly oppress, they are suffering.
From this, it is called heat, which arises from the realization of dharmas,
Arising from the sixteen aspects, contemplating the four noble truths.
From this point on, it is called the stage of heat. The arising of the good roots named heat is in the mindfulness of dharmas as objects of abandonment through cultivation.
Question:
How many aspects and what objects does it have?
Answer:
It arises from the sixteen aspects and observes the four noble truths.
The heat dharma has the sixteen aspects of the truth of suffering, and so on, the four aspects of the noble truth of suffering, up to the four aspects of the noble truth of the path.

The meaning of aspects will be explained in detail in the chapter on knowledge.ğŸ”½When the heat dharma arises, the mindfulness of dharmas as objects of abandonment through cultivation in the present is cultivated, and four are cultivated in the future. One aspect is cultivated in the present and four are cultivated in the future. It is one's own stage, not another's stage.

When the mindfulness of dharmas as objects of abandonment through cultivation in the present is cultivated, it is cultivated in the future. It is not the first cultivation of the path that takes the aggregates as its object, but one aspect is cultivated in the present and four are cultivated in the future.

Taking the three truths as objects and progressing through the four foundations of mindfulness, for each foundation of mindfulness, in the present one cultivates, and in the future four. In one practice, in the present one cultivates, and in the future sixteen.

Taking the truth of cessation as an object and progressing through the foundation of mindfulness of dharmas, in the present one cultivates, and in the future four. In one practice, in the present one cultivates, and in the future sixteen.
Cultivating the wholesome roots of non-increase, cultivating one's own wholesome roots.
In the present one cultivates, cultivating one's own, not cultivating one's own practice.
The dharma of heat is by nature wisdom, and the accompanying factors are by nature the five aggregates.
Heat is so called because it gives rise to the fire of holy knowledge, and because it is a seed.
This dharma, having grown, gives rise to the summit and forbearance,
And attains the supreme worldly dharmas, based on a single instant.

When this dharma has increased and the summit and patience have arisen, the practitioner's right effort and right mindfulness increase, and because of obtaining the conditions for the accumulation of good karma, the heat dharma increases and then gives rise to the good roots called the summit.

The summit dharma takes the four noble truths as its object and cultivates the sixteen aspects. It takes the four truths as its object, and when progressing in the dharma of mindfulness of cessation, it cultivates the present and future four, and cultivates the present one aspect and the future sixteen.
When progressing in the four mindfulnesses of the three truths, it cultivates the present and future four one by one, and cultivates the present one aspect and the future sixteen.
This good root is also of the nature of wisdom, and the accompanying dharmas are of the nature of the five aggregates.
The summit dharma is above the heat and is called the summit, and is inferior to patience and is called lower.
Sometimes the World-Honored One speaks of faith, as when speaking to the Parayan.
Sometimes he speaks of wisdom, as when speaking to the young bhikshus.
If one falls back from this peak experience, it is called falling back from the peak, or falling from the peak.
Warmth should also have falling back, but it is not mentioned.
Those who fall back from the peak experience much distress, therefore.

There are three places where one gives rise to great distress, like losing a great treasure: the desireless stage, the neither perception nor non-perception stage, and falling back from the desireless stage.
Falling back from the desireless stage and the peak experience is called the nature of non-accomplishment.

That practitioner, in this correct effort, accomplishes the peak wholesome roots, and in progress, gives rise to the acceptance of the truth in accordance with reality, taking the sixteen aspects of the four noble truths as objects.

The initial acceptance and the progress of the mindfulness of dharmas are cultivated in the present, and four are cultivated in the future, and one aspect is cultivated in the present, and sixteen are cultivated in the future.
Acceptance is the willingness and desire to endure the four noble truths.

Warmth and peak experience are also able to endure, but it is not so, because acceptance does not fall back, because it goes against the evil destinies, and because it is close to the noble path. Therefore, it is said that the acceptance in accordance with reality is not warmth or peak experience.
Question:
What wholesome roots does acceptance increase and give rise to?
Answer:

The attainment of the supreme worldly dharmas is based on a single moment, namely the supreme forbearance that arises in sequence, and is the most excellent wholesome root obtained by ordinary beings, called the supreme worldly dharmas. This also has the nature of the five aggregates.
Because they are contaminated, they are called worldly, and because they surpass heat and so forth, they are said to be supreme.

This is also the highest merit cultivated by ordinary beings, because it does not abide for a single moment, because it resembles the path of seeing, and because heat, summit, and forbearance are continuous.

Some say that wisdom cultivates the total contemplation of the mindfulness of dharmas, and in sequence gives rise to the wholesome roots of the determined worldly practices. They establish nine grades: the soft-soft, soft-middling, and soft-superior are called the dharmas of heat;
the middling-soft and middling-middling are called the dharmas of summit;
the middling-superior;
the superior-soft;
the superior-middling are called the dharmas of forbearance;
the superior-superior is called the supreme worldly dharmas.

If one contemplates the wholesome roots of the impermanence of the aggregates and so forth, it is called the dharma of heat. Contemplating the merits of the Three Jewels is called the dharma of summit. Observing the noble truths is called the dharma of patience. Contemplating the noble path in sequence to the noble truth of suffering is called the foremost dharma in the world.

Having attained the dharma of heat, if one regresses and abandons it, or abandons it at the end of life, or abandons it by transcending the realms and stages, one also commits uninterrupted offenses, severs wholesome roots, and is born in evil destinies. Due to this merit, one will definitely attain nirvana.
The regression of the dharma of summit is also like this, except for severing wholesome roots.

Patience does not regress, but there is abandonment at the end of life and abandonment by transcending the realms and stages. One does not commit uninterrupted offenses, does not sever wholesome roots, does not fall into evil destinies, because the power of patience is great.
It is like the king of lions, whom the beasts avoid from afar.
The power of patience is like this.
All evil minds are non-numerically extinguished, and it is also like the dwelling place of the great king, where the evil conduct of humans and gods is all softened.
Question:
What are the conditions and how many practices are there for the foremost dharma in the world?
Answer:
The lower suffering has four aspects, said to be included in six grounds,
The acceptance of knowledge is also like this, said to be included in seven grounds.
The four aspects of lower suffering refer to the suffering of the desire realm being said to be lower.
The object of the worldly supreme dharma is impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self, turning in these aspects and not others, because it is similar to the path of seeing.
There are two kinds of practitioners, those who practice based on desire and those who practice based on views.
Those who practice based on desire are of two kinds:
those who practice based on pride and those who practice based on laziness.
Those who practice based on views are also of two kinds:
those who cling to self and those who cling to what belongs to self.
Those who practice based on pride cultivate the worldly supreme dharma with the aspect of impermanence.
Those who practice based on laziness cultivate the aspect of suffering.ğŸ”½Those who cling to the notion of self cultivate the aspect of non-self.
Those who cling to the notion of what belongs to self cultivate the aspect of emptiness.
Question:
In how many grounds are they included?
Answer:
They are said to be included in six grounds, the future, intermediate, and four fundamental dhyanas.
Not in the desire realm, because there is no concentration;
Not in the formless realm, because there is no path of seeing.
Question:
How many stages are included in the other definite factors of enlightenment and wholesome roots?
Answer:
The factors of acceptance are also like this.
That is to say, acceptance is included in six stages, just like the supreme worldly dharmas.
That is to say, the other [factors of enlightenment] or based on seven. The heat and summit are also in six stages.
The Venerable Ghoá¹£a wishes to have them in the desire realm as well.
Question:
The definite factors of enlightenment have already been explained in their order of arising. How is the order of arising of the noble path?
Answer:
The supreme worldly dharmas are next born as the acceptance of the dharma of suffering,
Acceptance is next born as knowledge, both observing the suffering of the lower [realms].

The supreme worldly dharmas are next born as the acceptance of the dharma of suffering. The supreme worldly dharmas are next born as the acceptance of the dharma of suffering, which is the antidote to the ten defilements to be eliminated by seeing the suffering of the desire realm. This is then the first uncontaminated path of no-more-training.
Furthermore, the supreme worldly dharmas do not create, do not lead to, and do not engage in the subsequent [dharmas]. They abandon evil actions, evil destinies, and evil views.
Evil actions refer to the five heinous crimes. Evil destinies refer to the evil realms. Evil views refer to the five views.

Moreover, the supreme worldly dharmas determine the five kinds of certainty for the stage of the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing, namely the certainty of stage, the certainty of practice, the certainty of object, the certainty of moment, and the certainty of subsequent conditions.ğŸ”½The certainty of stage means that if the supreme worldly dharmas are of a certain stage, then the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing is also of that stage.
The certainty of practice means that if the supreme worldly dharmas are of a certain practice, then the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing is also of that practice.
The certainty of object means that [the two] must have the same object.

The certainty of moment means that if [the supreme worldly dharmas] arise in a certain moment, then [the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing] also arises in that same moment.
The certainty of subsequent conditions means that the supreme worldly dharmas necessarily give rise to the receptivity to the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing immediately afterward.
The stage of the receptivity to the knowledge of the path of seeing determines three kinds of certainty, excluding the certainty of moment and the certainty of subsequent conditions.

For this reason, after the acceptance of the truth of suffering, one attains the stage of non-returner. Contemplating the suffering of the desire realm and the suffering of the form and formless realms, up to the antidotes to the activities of the form and formless realms, this is called the lower acceptance.

They further contemplate the suffering of the desire realm up to the antidotes to the activities of the desire realm, abandoning the antidotes to the activities of the form and formless realms, this is the middle acceptance.

They observe each truth and abandon it, up to the continuous cultivation of the characteristics of suffering in the desire realm. Then they further abandon the continuity, up to contemplating the suffering of the desire realm in a single instant, this is the supreme acceptance. Then the worldly first dharmas arise.
After acceptance, knowledge arises. The knowledge of the law of suffering arises in succession to the acceptance of the law of suffering, the nature of the path of liberation.
Question:
What is the condition of this acceptance and knowledge?
Answer:
Together they contemplate the lower suffering.
The lower suffering is the suffering of the desire realm, they together contemplate that suffering.
Namely, the suffering of the form and formless realms, the arising, cessation, and path are also like this.
It is said that these sixteen minds are uninterrupted, etc.

As for the suffering of the form and formless realms, the acceptance of the observation of suffering is the uninterrupted path, and the knowledge of the observation of suffering is the path of liberation.

The same applies to the truths of accumulation, cessation, and the path. The two acceptances of the truths of accumulation, cessation, and the path are the uninterrupted paths, and the two knowledges are the paths of liberation.
It is said that these sixteen minds are uninterrupted, etc. At the time of these sixteen minds, they are uninterrupted, etc. Interrupted, etc. is the meaning of seeing.
At the time of these fifteen minds, it is the path of seeing. The last one mind is the path of cultivation.
Question:
Why are the acceptances and knowledges of the three truths included in the path of seeing, and the last mind of the truth of the path is included in the path of cultivation?
Answer:
Because one cultivates the path with the sixteen aspects.
The knowledge of the observation of the path cultivates the sixteen aspects, but the path of seeing does not cultivate the sixteen aspects.
Because the knowledge of the observation of the path is continuous, it is included in the path of fruition.

It means that if it is not appropriate, it is not so. If one who has attained the knowledge of exhaustion accomplishes this, then this is accomplished. If this is not the case, then the path of no-more-learning is also not the case.
In brief, there are three grounds:
The ground of seeing, the ground of cultivation, and the ground of no-more-learning. People are established on these grounds.
This meaning will now be explained.
The one of sharp faculties who practices in accordance with the teachings is in the fifteen minds,
And the one of dull faculties who practices in accordance with faith should be known to also be in the middle.

The one of sharp faculties who practices in accordance with the teachings is in the fifteen minds. If one of sharp faculties in the path of seeing is said to practice in accordance with the teachings,
Because one practices in accordance with the teachings, one is said to practice in accordance with the teachings, and not because one follows the faith of others.

The one of dull faculties who practices in accordance with faith should be known to also be in the middle. If one of dull faculties in the fifteen minds is said to practice in accordance with faith, it is because one attains liberation by trusting others.
One who practices in accordance with faith has little contemplation, while one who practices in accordance with the teachings has much contemplation.
Those who follow faith and those who follow the teachings, if they are bound by afflictions,
Up to those who have severed five types, should be known as approaching the first fruit.
This person who follows faith and the teachings, if they are bound by afflictions, if they have severed one, two, three, four, or five types, is called approaching the fruit of stream-entry.
The afflictions are established as nine grades based on distinctions such as upper-upper.
If they have not severed even one grade while still an ordinary person, they are called fully bound.
If they have severed one grade, they are called not fully bound. If they have severed five grades, they transcend and are born in the pure abodes.
Severing five grades of the afflictions to be eliminated by seeing suffering in the desire realm, one attains the realization of liberation through the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing.

Up to severing five grades of the afflictions to be eliminated by seeing the path in the desire realm, one attains the realization of liberation through the knowledge of the factors of the path of seeing.
Severing five grades of the afflictions to be eliminated by the path of cultivation in the desire realm, one attains the realization of liberation through the fruit of once-returning.
Severing six to eight grades, one approaches the second fruit.
Free from desire up to the eighth stage, one then approaches the third fruit.

Those who have eliminated up to the eighth [afflictions] are progressing towards the second fruit. This refers to those of the faith-follower and Dharma-follower types who have already eliminated six, seven, or eight categories [of afflictions]. They are said to be progressing towards the fruit of once-returning.

Those who are detached up to the eighth stage are progressing towards the third [fruit]. This refers to those of the faith-follower and Dharma-follower types who are detached from desire up to the end of the sphere of nothingness. They are both progressing towards the fruit of non-returning.
If they reach the sixteenth moment of mind, they are said to abide in the fruit.
Those with dull faculties and view are liberation by faith, those with sharp faculties and view are liberation by insight.

If they reach the sixteenth moment of mind, they are said to abide in the fruit. The sixteenth moment of mind is called the path of subsequent knowledge. They and their accompanying [attainments] are said to abide in the fruit, whether as a stream-enterer, once-returner, or non-returner.

Those with dull faculties and view are liberation by faith. If one with dull faculties enters the path of seeing, they are called faith-followers. When they abide in the three fruits, they are called liberation by faith.
Those with sharp faculties who enter the path of seeing are called followers of the dharma. When they abide in the three fruits, they are called those who attain through views.
Those who attain through views have the faculty of faith surpassing, and are liberated through faith. However, because they are perfumed by wisdom, they are said to attain through views.
Not all afflictions are eliminated, that is, all are exhausted,
Up to not yet engaging in practice, this is called a stream-enterer.
If the eighty-eight bonds eliminated by the path of seeing are exhausted, this is the fruit of stream-entry.
Up to not yet accumulating practice, this is called abiding in the fruit of stream-entry.
If one eliminates the highest type through skillful means, this is called approaching the fruit of once-returning.

This type up to the fifth category of elimination, transcending birth through the arising of the subsequent knowledge of the path, is called stream-entry, not approaching once-returning, because the path approaching that fruit has not yet appeared even for a moment.
Question:
Why did the World-Honored One speak of the exhaustion of the three bonds in eliminating many afflictions?
Answer:
The ten defilements are the roots:
The five views, doubt, craving, hatred, pride, and ignorance.
Among them, the six that are eliminated by the path of seeing are the five views and doubt.
Those six defilements that are eliminated by the path of seeing are completely eliminated.

Those three that are turned and three that are followed are as follows: The view of self is turned, and the extreme view is followed. The grasping of precepts and vows is turned, and the grasping of views is followed. Doubt is turned, and wrong views are followed.
Having explained what is turned, one should understand what is followed.
Therefore the World-Honored One said:
The exhaustion of the three fetters is the stream-enterer.
Furthermore, these defilements are either of one kind, two kinds, or four kinds.
Having explained the view of self, one should understand that one kind has been explained.
Having explained the grasping of precepts and vows, one should understand that two kinds have been explained.
Having explained doubt, one should understand that four kinds have been explained.
In this way, all-pervading and non-all-pervading, defiled objects and undefiled objects should be understood as exhausted.
Even for arhats, there is still a similar continuity because this bond has already been exhausted and known.
Those who have not exhausted the seeds of the path of cultivation will be reborn seven times.
It should be known that what they say is the maximum for stream-enterers.
For those stream-enterers who have not exhausted the seeds of the path of cultivation, it should be known that their maximum is seven existences.
Seven births in the human realm, intermediate state, and desire realm heavens are collectively called seven existences, because they do not exceed seven, like a tree with seven leaves.
Question:
Why are seven existences said to be neither more nor less?
Answer:
Like one bitten by a seven-step snake, due to the power of the four elements they reach seven steps, but due to the power of the poison they do not reach eight.
In the same way, due to the power of karma there are seven births, but due to the power of the path there are not eight.
When they abide in the supreme patience, except for the seven births in the desire realm, all other births attain the cessation not attained through deliberate effort and will never appear again.

If one is born in the human realm and then ascends to the heavens, one will complete [the path] in the heavens. Even if the noble path appears in the intermediate state, due to the power of karma, one does not attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Question:
If one completes seven rebirths and the Buddha does not appear in the world, how can one attain the fruit of arhatship?
Answer:
Some say that one attains the fruit of arhatship as a layperson, but after attaining the fruit, one does not remain a layperson.

It is also said that one immediately renounces the householder's life, because one possesses unshakable purity, because one's hopes are fulfilled, and because one sees the faults of misconduct. Therefore, the Dharma of the stream-enterer does not fall into evil destinies.

Moreover, because one is born in the lineage of the Buddha, because the fire of wisdom is pure and bright, because one sees the faults of the objects of the senses, because one possesses tranquility and insight, and because one is perfumed by the medicine of the noble path, like a prince, like one whose inner fire increases, and like a skillful fish, therefore the stream-enterer does not fall into evil destinies.

Although ordinary people do not fall into evil destinies, they are not mentioned because they are few and uncertain, but they are said to be definitely established because they abide in the stage of definite goodness, and they are said to be heading for right enlightenment because they will certainly attain nirvana.
The seven existences are as explained above.
Abiding refers to the intermediate state, and birth refers to the birth state, so it is said to abide and be born.
No longer accepting other births, it is called abiding at the edge of suffering.
It is not necessarily the case that all srota-Äpannas will reach the limit of seven existences.
If one severs three or four kinds [of afflictions], and accomplishes their antidotes,
with two or three remaining births, this is called a family-to-family [returner].
For three reasons, the family-to-family [returner] is established, namely, severing afflictions, accomplishing faculties, and taking rebirth.

As for severing afflictions, one severs three or four grades of afflictions to be eliminated through cultivation in the desire realm, but there is no one who severs five grades and is called a family-to-family [returner].
If one can sever five classes, by the power of that, one will definitely sever six classes and become a once-returner. The power of the sixth class cannot obstruct one from attaining the fruit.
One who has accomplished the faculties obtains the antidote, which is the uncontaminated faculties.
One who is reborn may be reborn in the desire realm again, either twice or three times.
If any one of the three conditions is not fulfilled, one is not a once-returner.
There are two kinds of once-returners:
those who are reborn among the gods and those who are reborn among humans.
As for those reborn among the gods, it means the gods of the desire realm, who may be reborn twice or three times, or may take on the form of one kind of god, or two or three.
As for those reborn among humans, it means human bodies, either in one continent, or two or three, or in one family, or two or three.
Question:
What is the meaning of once-returner?
Answer:ğŸ”½Because one attains nirvana by going from family to family, it is called once-returner.
The superior stream-enterer is called a once-returner.
The six types of afflictions are eliminated, and all those eliminated by the path of seeing,
Are called once-returners, who have not yet progressed.

If in the desire realm, the upper three types and middle three types eliminated by the path of cultivation, and all eliminated by the path of seeing are exhausted, abiding in the fruit without progressing, it is called once-returner.
Question:
What is the meaning of once-returner?
Answer:
After death here, they are born among the desire realm gods, return to the human realm once, and then attain parinirvÄá¹‡a.
If seven or eight types are eliminated, and the faculties of the antidotes are accomplished,
The remaining one life is received, which is called the single-seeded.

If in the desire realm, seven or eight types eliminated by the path of cultivation, and all eliminated by the path of seeing are exhausted, attaining the antidotes' uncontaminated faculties, the remaining one life in the desire realm is called single-seeded.
If any one of the three causes is not complete, it is not single-seeded.
If a single-seeded god receives one divine body and then attains parinirvÄá¹‡a;
It is the same for humans.
Because they plant the seeds for one more life, they are called those with one more birth.
Question:
Why is the severing of eight categories called having one more birth?
Why is the severing of five categories not called a once-returner?
Answer:
Even if one who has severed six categories is a once-returner, they still take birth in the desire realm. Therefore, the karma and afflictions of the desire realm do not create obstacles.

One who has severed nine categories and is born in the form realm is called one with one more birth. Therefore, the karma and afflictions of the desire realm create the greatest obstacles. For this reason, it is said that the karma of beings in the three realms creates the greatest disturbance.
The three realms will be explained later.
One with one more birth is the highest once-returner.
Those who have severed nine categories and are non-returners should be known as of many kinds,
Either five, seven, or eight, or else it is said to be numerous.

Those who have severed nine categories and are non-returners should be known as non-returners who have severed all that is to be severed by the path of seeing and the nine categories of bonds to be severed by the path of cultivation in the desire realm.
Question:
Why did the World-Honored One say that the destruction of the five lower bonds is the non-returner?
Answer:
The five kinds of two, four, and five all include the five lower bonds.
The meanings of detestable and lowly are the same.
Moreover, there are two kinds of lower:
The lower realm and the lower sentient beings.
The lower realm is the desire realm, and the lower sentient beings are ordinary beings, bound by greed and anger.
The lower realm is difficult to cross, bound by the views of self, adherence to precepts, and doubt.
The lower sentient beings are like guards and sentries.
The noble ones may first destroy two or three bonds, but because they are accumulated and destroyed, five are mentioned.
Returning to the desire realm is called the non-returner.
This also has many kinds, either five, seven, or eight, or it is said to be numerous.

As for the five types of non-returners mentioned, they are: those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth, those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a through practice, those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice, and those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a as a stream-enterer.

Seventh, there are three types of those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, as stated in the sÅ«tras. The three types are: 1) like a small spark of fire, 2) like a small piece of hot iron, and 3) like a spark of burning iron.
This is the same as the four mentioned in the sÅ«tras.
Eighth, the five types are as mentioned above.

Moreover, for those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the present life, non-returners in the formless realm and those of indeterminate type, the establishment of five faculties in the form realm is fifteen.
Those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state have faculties of lower, middle, and upper levels, and the same is true for those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a as a stream-enterer.
Ninth, the establishment of realms is twenty:
The first dhyÄna has five, and the fourth dhyÄna also has five.
Tenth, the establishment of types is thirty:

There are six types of those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, namely those of the nature of retrogression, those of the nature of reflection, those of the nature of protection, those of the nature of abiding, those of the nature of progress, and those of the nature of immovability.
In the same way, up to those who go upstream are also like this.
In terms of location, there are eighty:
Five for the BrahmakÄyika gods, and so on, up to Akaniá¹£á¹­ha.
In terms of nature and faculties, there are ninety.
In terms of nature and stages, there are one hundred and twenty.
In terms of nature, stages, and faculties, there are three hundred and sixty.ğŸ”½In terms of nature and location, there are four hundred and eighty.
In terms of nature, location, and faculties, there are one thousand four hundred and forty.
The commentary says:
Fifteen, twenty, thirty, and eighty,
Ninety, one hundred and twenty, and three hundred and sixty,
Four hundred and eighty kinds, one thousand four hundred and forty,
Thus broadly and briefly explained, subsuming the non-returners.
And the places, is extensive.ğŸ”½According to the elimination of afflictions,
I will now explain in order.
Next, one non-returner, namely one who attains parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.

The establishment of faculties is three, the stages are four, the lineages are six, the places are sixteen, the faculties and lineages are eighteen, the stages and lineages are twenty-four, the stages and detachment are thirty-six, the stages, lineages, and faculties are seventy-two, the lineages and places are ninety-six, the stages, lineages, and detachment are two hundred sixteen, the lineages, faculties, and places are two hundred eighty-eight, the stages, lineages, faculties, and detachment are six hundred forty-eight, the places, lineages, and detachment are eight hundred sixty-four, and the establishment of the places, lineages, faculties, and detachment is two thousand five hundred ninety-two.
One should know that this is the number of those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
Up to those who go upstream are also like this.
All of these together include twelve thousand nine hundred sixty.
Record says:
Sixteen and eighteen,
Are said to be twenty-four, and again thirty-six,
Seventy-two kinds, and ninety-six kinds,
One hundred and sixteen, and one hundred and eighteen,
Six hundred and forty-eight, and eight hundred and sixty-four,
And again, it is said to be two thousand, five hundred and ninety-two.
Thus, the number of non-returners is five times the above two thousand five hundred ninety-two, which is five times ten thousand two hundred ninety.
All non-returners have been explained. The characteristics of the five non-returners will now be explained.
Those with sharp faculties and weak afflictions abide in one kind of karma,
And attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state, distinguished by six natures.

Those of sharp faculties and weak afflictions abide in one kind of karma. This refers to those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state. This person has sharp faculties and weak afflictions. They create karma for the intermediate state and do not create karma for the birth state. They pass away in the desire realm and abide in the intermediate state of the form realm. They attain the uncontaminated path and abandon the remaining bonds through this path, and then attain parinirvÄá¹‡a. This is called parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state.
Because it is difficult to cross over the desire realm, one does not attain parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state of the desire realm.

If one wishes to attain parinirvÄá¹‡a, they should sever the two kinds of bonds of wholesome and indeterminate [karma], attain the fruits of the two or three Å›ramaá¹‡as, and transcend the three realms;
but in the intermediate state of the desire realm, this is not possible.
If one passes away in the form realm, they are included in the category of those who go upstream.
Question:
How many types of natures does this person have?
Answer:
Six types of natures are distinguished.
It should be known that parinirvÄá¹‡a in the intermediate state has six types of natures, from the nature of falling away up to the immovable.
If it is said that those with sharp faculties should not regress in their spiritual lineage, that is not so, because they also establish nine levels of faculties.
Through diligent effort and skillful means, one cultivates the path of swift progress,
and attains parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth. There are also two explanations for this.

As for those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth through diligent effort, skillful means, and cultivation of the path of swift progress, those who attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth create karma for the intermediate state and the state of rebirth, and upon death they experience the intermediate state and rebirth in the form realm heavens.

When they first take rebirth, they cultivate the path of practice, that is, diligent effort and the path of swift progress, quickly severing the remaining bonds, and attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon first taking rebirth. Therefore, it is said that they attain parinirvÄá¹‡a upon rebirth.

As for there being also two explanations for this, some say that if one attains parinirvÄá¹‡a by severing afflictions upon first taking rebirth, that is not so, because there is no division of the practice of relinquishing life.
There is no practice of relinquishing life, and one abides until the end of one's life.
This meaning is superior.
The third, through diligent effort, is apart from the path of swift progress,
The fourth is not diligent in seeking, with all three having six kinds.

The third is diligent in expedient means, but separated from the path of rapid progress. If there are differences in their practice of parinirvÄá¹‡a, they do not practice the path of rapid progress, and the rest is as explained above.
The name is: giving rise to the path with activity, cutting off the remaining afflictions, and attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a. This is parinirvÄá¹‡a through practice.
Moreover, relying on the samÄdhi of conditioned objects, cutting off afflictions and attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a, is also parinirvÄá¹‡a through practice.
The fourth is not diligent in seeking. This is parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice. It is also not diligent in seeking and does not practice the path of rapid progress. The rest is as explained above.
The name is: giving rise to the path without activity, cutting off the remaining afflictions, and attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a. This is parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice.
Moreover, relying on the samÄdhi of unconditioned objects, cutting off afflictions and attaining parinirvÄá¹‡a, is also parinirvÄá¹‡a without practice.
The third, speaking of all six kinds, means that those who attain nirvana through birth are said to be of six natures, both those who practice and those who do not practice.
Although these three are all those who attain nirvana through birth, there is no error in speaking of three because of the differences in meaning.
Those who transcend, partially transcend, and transcend everywhere are called those who go upstream.
These are also of six natures, known as those who progress and those who do not progress.
Those who go upstream are of two kinds:
those who have previously attained dhyÄna meditation and those who have not.

Those who have previously attained first cultivate and perfect the three dhyÄnas, but later regress and abide in the first dhyÄna. They are bound to the characteristics of the first dhyÄna and are reborn in the Brahma Heaven.
They are also of three kinds:
those who transcend, those who partially transcend, and those who die everywhere.

Those who transcend are reborn in the first dhyÄna and up to those who are free from desire for the third dhyÄna. They cultivate and perfect the fourth dhyÄna, and when their life ends they are reborn in the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha Heaven.
Those who partially transcend are those who, after passing away from the Brahma heaven, are born in one, two, or three places, and then are born in the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven.
Those who pass away from all places are those who are born in each place up to the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven.
Those who have not previously attained the perfuming [of the seeds] are not born in the Pure Abodes, but are born in the formless realm. The rest is as explained above.
Question:
How many types of natures are there?
Answer:
There are also six types of natures here.
The upward stream also has six types of natures, from the type subject to regression up to the immovable type.

This is not the immovable type of nature that abides in the first stage. That is to say, the type subject to regression, after regressing from the perfumed cultivation of dhyÄna, later attains the state of seeing the truths.

One should know that those who advance and those who do not advance, one should know that there are those who advance and those who do not advance in the upward stream. Four alternatives should be made.
Those who should advance and cultivate but are not advancing are those who abide in the desire realm and the Brahma heaven.
Those who are not advancing and do not should advance are those who abide in the Akaniá¹£á¹­ha heaven.
Those who are advancing and are not advancing are those who abide in the other heavens.
Neither progressing nor not progressing means non-existent.
If one is heading towards the formless realm, one is not cultivating, therefore it is said that one is born in the formless realm.
Question:
The World-Honored One spoke of seven courses of action for human beings.
How are the seven courses of action for human beings established?
Answer:
It is said that there are three kinds based on birth, faculties, and afflictions,
And there are also three kinds based on non-birth, as well as two kinds of upward progressers and one.

One non-returner is established as seven kinds for four reasons, namely the establishment of faculties, the establishment of afflictions, the establishment of birth and non-birth, and the establishment of upward progress.
Among them, those who are born are of sharp faculties and weak afflictions in the beginning.
The second are of middling faculties and middling afflictions.
The third are of dull faculties and strong afflictions.
Just as there are three kinds of birth, there are also three kinds of non-birth.
As for the upward progressers, they are said to progress upward. Because ordinary beings turn back, they are not upward progressers.
The upper stream in the formless realm has five superior things, namely, realm superiority, ground superiority, superior acceptance, reduction of aggregates, and severing of afflictions.
Although there are five superior things, they cannot cultivate perfuming, and therefore the course of a person is not established.
Thus, these nine afflictions are in the upper eight grounds,
It is said by the World-Honored One that they are extinguished by the double path.
Thus, these nine afflictions are in the upper eight grounds. Just as the afflictions to be eliminated by the path of cultivation in the desire realm have nine grades, from soft-soft to soft-upper.

The upper eight grounds are also like this, namely, the four dhyanas and the four formless [absorptions]. When the initial path of seeing arises, it eliminates the nine kinds of afflictions by one kind of path.
Question:
If the afflictions of the form and formless realms are also of nine kinds, why are they not established as persons who have separated from desire?
Answer:
Because the two births in one place are not possible.
In the desire realm, there are such heavens, such directions, such families, and the noble ones have two births, not the noble ones of the form and formless realms have two births.
If one has two births, there is no birth parinirvÄá¹‡a up to the stream-enterer.

As for what the World-Honored One said about the cessation of the two paths, it should be known that the cessation of the afflictions of the three realms is the cessation of the unobstructed path and liberation path. The unobstructed path is able to sever afflictions and attain the liberation path, attaining the realization of liberation.
The unobstructed path severs afflictions, and the liberation path does not lose what has been done, thus it is said that the two paths cease.
If it is said that the liberation path severs afflictions, then how?
Is it arisen or not yet arisen?
If it is arisen, then when the first knowledge of exhaustion arises, there should be afflictions, and this is not ultimate.
If it is not yet arisen, should the future path not sever afflictions?
Question:
For what path does it sever afflictions?
Answer:
The defiled and undefiled paths are both able to abandon the eight stages.
Abiding there is called bodily realization, which is said to be the attainment of cessation.
The defiled and undefiled paths are both able to abandon the eight stages. The defiled one is the worldly path, the undefiled one is the holy path.
Except for the summit of existence, in the other stages when abandoning desires, one should know there are both contaminated and uncontaminated paths.
In abandoning the summit of existence, there is only the uncontaminated path. The contaminated path is not a factor there.
Because the worldly path clings to higher stages, it abandons the afflictions of lower stages like a mole cricket.

The stage of neither-perception-nor-non-perception has no higher stage to cling to, so it is able to abandon those bonds. Because it is bound to its own stage, it cannot abandon the bonds of its own stage.
It is like a person who is bound and cannot unbind himself.
That worldly unobstructed path has three aspects:ğŸ”½coarse, suffering, and coarse obstacles.
Because it is manifest, it is said to be coarse. Because it is composed of the three sufferings, it is said to be suffering. Because it is easy to contemplate, it is said to be a coarse obstacle.
The path of liberation also has three aspects:
That is to say, tranquility, subtlety, and transcendence, each of which is an unobstructed path.
The lower-level path of liberation takes liberation as its object, and the higher-level path takes the noble path as its object. This will be explained later.

It is said that one who attains the samÄdhi of cessation and abides in it is a body witness. One who attains the samÄdhi of cessation and abides in the path of seeing that eliminates the afflictions of the eight stages and the path of seeing that eliminates the afflictions of one stage is called a body witness.
Therefore, a learner who has attained the summit of existence and is free from desire in each stage can give rise to the samÄdhi of cessation.
They may attain the samÄdhi of cessation while still bound by all the bonds, or they may attain it upon the exhaustion of the eighth category [of afflictions].

Because the World-Honored One has transcended all samÄdhis, he is said to have transcended all the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, to have realized the cessation of perception and feeling with his body, and to abide in the Dharma of perfect freedom. Because nirvana is united with the body, it is said to be realized with the body.
The samÄdhi of cessation will be explained in detail in the chapter on samÄdhi.
The vajra-like samÄdhi is followed by the knowledge of exhaustion,
The mind of birth thinks, My births are ended, and is worthy of offerings, free from all defilements.

The vajra-like concentration is necessarily followed by the knowledge of destruction. The ninth unhindered path of detachment from the stage of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is called the vajra-like samadhi.
Because there is nothing that it does not destroy, it is called vajra.
This meaning will be explained in detail in the chapter on discrimination.

The vajra concentration is necessarily followed by the knowledge of destruction. This first two knowledges may be the inferential knowledge of suffering or the inferential knowledge of accumulation. The mind of birth thinks, My births are ended.
Because the four aggregates of the stage of neither-perception-nor-non-perception have a fundamental basis.

Worthy of offerings, free from all defilements means that when the knowledge of destruction arises, all contaminated [dharmas] are exhausted, and it is called worthy of offerings because it is worthy of all offerings, because it has destroyed all afflictions, and because it no longer plants the seeds of consciousness in existence.

For an immovable arhat, when the knowledge of exhaustion arises immediately after the knowledge of non-arising, that knowledge of exhaustion is one moment, and the knowledge of non-arising is either one moment, or if the same view is present immediately afterwards, it is one moment, but if the knowledge of non-arising is present, it continues.

For one liberated by wisdom, the knowledge of exhaustion is either one moment, or if the same view is present immediately afterwards, it is one moment, but if the knowledge of exhaustion is present, it continues.
Question:
How many kinds of arhats are there?
Answer:
Arhats are of six kinds, born as followers of faith, five,
They attain two knowledges, to be known as temporarily liberated.

Arhats are of six kinds, namely those liable to fall away, those who will attain final nirvana in this life, those who guard the path, those who are firmly established, those who are bound to progress, and the immovable.
If one is on the stage of initial learning, not constantly applying oneself, not suddenly applying oneself, this is called liable to fall away.
Those who will attain final nirvana in this life are also like this, able to contemplate and vow.
One who guards the Dharma always uses skillful means and not sudden means, because by guarding it one does not regress.
One who abides in the Dharma uses sudden means and not always skillful means, and neither regresses nor advances.
One who necessarily advances always uses skillful means and sudden means, and is of dull faculties, able to attain the immovable.
One of immovable Dharma always uses skillful and sudden means, and is of sharp faculties.
Some say that one of the regressing type necessarily regresses, up to one of the necessarily advancing type necessarily advances.
They say that these six are arhats of the desire realm.
The form and formless realms have two types: one who abides in the Dharma and one of immovable Dharma.
Some say that one of the regressing type does not necessarily regress, and if one regresses it is only this type and not others.
They say that all three realms have six types of arhats.
As for those born as followers of faith, they possess two knowledges, namely the knowledge of exhaustion and the view of those beyond training.
Because they sometimes regress, the knowledge of non-arising is not mentioned.
The World-Honored One, because of no longer accepting rebirth, in all sutras speaks of knowing as it truly is the non-arising of future existence.
One should know that those liberated at times are liberated at times because of following the teachings and people who speak of robes, food, bedding, and dwelling places.
Because they cannot progress in the wholesome roots at all times as they wish, they are called liberated at times.
Those of unshakable nature with sharp faculties are liberated independent of times.
They attain three knowledges and accomplish their own liberation.

Those of unshakable nature with sharp faculties are liberated independent of times. If those of unshakable nature are of single-minded sharp faculties, they are able to cultivate wholesome actions at all times as they wish, without relying on conditions.
Those who are occasionally liberated and possess three knowledges possess three knowledges:
the knowledge of extinction, the knowledge of non-arising, and the view of non-learning, which is the Dharma of non-retrogression.
Those who are liberated by self-realization and accomplishment should be known as those who are similar to themselves, called liberated and accomplished.
Those who are liberated by the mind at the right time are called liberated by the mind at the right time because they depend on the right time.

Those who are liberated by the mind at the right time and possess the Dharma of non-retrogression are called liberated by the mind at the right time and possess the Dharma of non-retrogression because they are immovable.
Because they are not moved by afflictions, it is said to be non-retrogression.
Question:
Why is liberation by the mind at the right time called love, but not immovability?
Answer:
Because they are extremely self-protective.
Like a one-eyed person, they are not free because they fear retrogression.
Like borrowing things from others, they are not part of the wholesome roots that are bound to that.
